Which one of the following tests is most appropriate next in this patient’s diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anemia is a common complication of chronic kidney disease but is uncommon when the estimated glomerular filtration rate is >45 mL/min/1.73m2 . This patient’s decline in hemoglobin is out of proportion to the decline in renal function and is substantial for a 6-month period. In these cases, further evaluation is warranted. This patient has already undergone iron studies, vitamin B12 and folate testing, and screening colonoscopy, all of which were normal. The most appropriate next step — given his increased serum creatinine level, hypercalcemia with a low-normal parathyroid hormone level (ruling out primary hyperparathyroidism), and proteinuria — is serum protein immunoelectrophoresis to test for multiple myeloma.

Anemia is present in approximately 73% of patients at the time of multiple myeloma diagnosis. It is generally related to marrow infiltration or renal impairment, which occurs as a result of direct tubular damage from excess protein load, dehydration, and hypercalcemia.

Key learning point: In a patient with hypercalcemia, proteinuria, and anemia disproportionate to the degree of chronic kidney disease, a prompt diagnostic evaluation should be done to evaluate for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Sleep-disordered breathing would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Kidney ultrasound would have a low diagnostic yield in a patient without obstructive urinary symptoms whose clinical findings indicate a systemic disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A intoxication is a rare cause of hypercalcemia but would not explain this patient’s anemia and increasing proteinuria.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis for the past 8 years presents with back and pelvic pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and congestive heart failure. His medications include amlodipine, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, sevelamer carbonate, intravenous iron, and darbepoetin. He has been intermittently adherent to treatment.
On examination, his blood pressure is 96/55 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 94% while he is breathing ambient air.
Laboratory results from one month ago are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
8.6
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
7.3
3.0–4.5



Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
945
10–60



Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
205
30–120


CT of the pelvis is obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely etiology of the patient's bone lesions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a common complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Great strides have been made in the understanding of the pathophysiology of this disorder in the past decade. The current understanding of the disease process is as follows:

• A reduced nephron number leads to a reduction in phosphate excretion.
• This results in an increase in fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF-23) secretion from bone osteocytes and osteoblasts, which helps increase urinary phosphorus excretion and thus maintain normal serum phosphate levels.
• The increased FGF-23 also suppresses renal 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity, thus reducing calcitriol production.
• Reduced calcitriol leads to a reduction in calcium absorption and thus a tendency to hypocalcemia.
• This stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which liberates calcium along with phosphate from bone and normalizes serum calcium levels.
• PTH also acts on the renal tubules to reduce reabsorption of phosphate and therefore increase excretion.
• As renal function continues to decline, further increases in FGF-23 and PTH cannot normalize the serum phosphate, and frank hyperphosphatemia develops. The elevated serum phosphorus level serves as a second direct stimulus to the release of PTH.
• There may also be worsening of hypocalcemia from extraskeletal calcium phosphate precipitation.

These adaptations, designed to maintain normal calcium and phosphate homeostasis via secondary hyperparathyroidism, lead to bone demineralization.

Management of secondary hyperparathyroidism involves (1) reducing serum phosphorus with reduced phosphate intake and oral phosphate binders, and (2) avoiding hypocalcemia by administering calcium and calcitriol or its analogues. Cinacalcet, a calcimimetic, can also be used to reduce PTH levels.

If the secondary hyperparathyroidism is not controlled, the parathyroid glands will continue to be stimulated and can become hypertrophied with autonomous function, thus becoming unresponsive to conventional therapy and normal homeostatic stimuli. This has been called tertiary hyperparathyroidism. The broader clinical syndrome encompassing mineral, bone, and calcific cardiovascular abnormalities that develop as a complication of CKD is called CKD-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD).

Elevated PTH increases osteoclastic turnover of bone and can result in localized regions of rapid bone loss with hemorrhage, reparative granulation tissue, and vascular, proliferating fibrous tissue replacing normal marrow contents. These benign lesions, called brown tumors or osteoclastomas, are named for their hemosiderin content. Radiographically, they appear as well-defined lytic lesions with little reactive bone and thin, expanded cortices.

Key learning point: In a patient with severe, long-standing hyperparathyroidism, expansive lytic lesions of the skeleton are most likely due to renal osteodystrophy (brown tumors).

B) INCORRECT:

Paget disease is associated with a mix of sclerotic and lytic lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma is not typically associated with an elevated PTH level, but additional testing is warranted to exclude myeloma.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is usually associated with sclerotic metastatic bone lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell tumors are typically solitary.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman with a history of renal-cell carcinoma and end-stage kidney disease is evaluated for chronic diffuse skin thickening. She reports that the symptoms started approximately 8 years ago. At that time, she was seen by a dermatologist and was referred for physical therapy. The skin findings have been stable since then.
The patient's history is notable for a diagnosis of renal-cell carcinoma 10 years ago. She underwent a right radical nephrectomy and had several MRI scans with gadolinium contrast in the first 2 years after the surgery, with no evidence of disease recurrence. Before the nephrectomy, she had preexisting diabetic kidney disease with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 (reference range, ≥60). After the surgery, she had a decline in kidney function and, 7 years ago, developed end-stage kidney disease requiring dialysis.
On examination, she has thickening of the skin that extends proximally to her arms and legs (figure).
Her C-reactive protein level has been persistently elevated at 40 mg/liter (reference range, 0.8–3.1). Her antinuclear antibody test is negative.
A skin biopsy shows marked thickening of the dermis, with florid proliferation of fibrocytes with long dendritic processes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scleromyxedema, also known as papular mucinosis, is characterized by large mucinous deposits in the dermis, which appear as waxy yellow-red papules over thickened and indurated skin; it is associated with abnormal serum light chains.

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic fasciitis is associated with eosinophilic infiltration of skin, which was not seen on the skin biopsy in this case.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's skin findings are consistent with nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF). NSF is characterized by thickening and induration of the skin overlying the extremities, with marked expansion and fibrosis of the dermis; the process can also involve internal organs, such as the lungs, heart, and muscles.

NSF was seen in the past when older formulations of gadolinium that were chelated with linear ligands for clinical use were administered to patients with severely reduced kidney function. The effect appeared to be cumulative, such that individuals who had greater exposure were at greater risk. These formulations are no longer marketed in the United States and Europe but were likely administered to this patient when she had her postoperative scans. Currently used formulations of gadolinium contrast appear to be very safe, as acknowledged in the 2021 consensus report from the American College of Radiology and the National Kidney Foundation. This report stated that NSF is very unlikely even in patients with an estimated glomerular filtration rate ≤30 mL/min/1.73 m2 and that dialysis should not be initiated nor the regimen altered for gadolinium administration.

Key learning point: The administration of older formulations of gadolinium contrast to patients with advanced kidney disease is associated with fibrosing dermopathy (nephrogenic systemic fibrosis).

D) INCORRECT:

A drug eruption would not be expected to cause fibrosis of the dermis.

E) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma manifests with thickened, hardened skin that involves the fingers, hands, and face early in its course. It is usually associated with a positive antinuclear antibody test.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman has well-controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ischemic heart disease, and type 2 diabetes complicated by diabetic nephropathy and chronic kidney disease that has gradually progressed during the past 5 years.
At her most recent evaluation 3 months ago, her serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1), with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 19 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥60). Her medications include insulin degludec, simvastatin, metoprolol, lisinopril, furosemide, calcium acetate, and aspirin.
On examination, her heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. She has clear lungs and trace edema.

Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs) can be used to treat anemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD), but this patient's current hemoglobin value is already within the target range for patients with CKD. Furthermore, ESAs have not been shown to delay the progression of CKD.

B) INCORRECT:

Although high uric acid levels are associated with progression to end-stage kidney disease, randomized controlled trials have not shown that allopurinol slows progression of chronic kidney disease.

C) INCORRECT:

The addition of metolazone could be considered for a patient who has elevated blood pressure and significant edema, but this patient has neither.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's bicarbonate level of 16 mEq/liter most likely represents a metabolic acidosis. Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) may develop metabolic acidosis as their estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) declines, particularly when it drops below 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 . Dietary interventions, such as replacing animal protein with plant-derived proteins, can help limit the development of metabolic acidosis. However, if significant metabolic acidosis develops despite dietary interventions, most experts recommend treating it with sodium bicarbonate therapy because persistently low serum bicarbonate levels are associated with progression of CKD.

The recommendation for sodium bicarbonate therapy is supported by two randomized controlled trials that conclusively showed benefits from this approach, with a slower annual decline in kidney function, fewer patients needing dialysis, and improved overall survival in the group treated with sodium bicarbonate (as compared with placebo). Additional proposed benefits of treating metabolic acidosis in CKD include improved nutritional status and improved bone health (by limiting bone buffering). Of note, treating metabolic acidosis with sodium bicarbonate therapy has not been proven to be beneficial in the transplant setting.

Key learning point: Bicarbonate therapy should be considered in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease and significant metabolic acidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with a non-calcium-containing phosphate binder, such as sevelamer, is not indicated in patients with normal serum phosphate levels, although individuals with chronic kidney disease should be encouraged to limit processed foods with highly available phosphate. Non-calcium-containing phosphate binders have gained popularity because of concern that the use of calcium-based binders to lower serum phosphorus might increase cardiovascular risk in patients with reduced renal function, but the benefits of these agents have not been proven.

She reports that she feels fatigue and some dyspnea when climbing stairs; she also has chronic constipation. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Increase the dose of oral iron

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Red-cell transfusion is rarely used unless the patient has a hemoglobin concentration of ≤7 g/dL, is experiencing angina, has unstable cardiac function, is actively bleeding, or is being prepared for a surgical procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an increase in oral ferrous replacement is an option, it is unlikely to make a substantial difference since the patient's iron indices are relatively low despite the fact that she is already taking oral iron. In addition, this patient is taking two medications for constipation, and an increase in oral iron is likely to worsen her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is not sufficient in a patient with significant anemia who has low iron stores.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) are recommended in patients with anemia of CKD, with a goal hemoglobin level of 10 to 11.5 g/dL. However, these agents are not recommended in patients with active cancer. In several studies, including randomized controlled trials, patients with active cancer were found to have increased mortality and/or increased risk for tumor progression when treated with ESAs.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), erythropoietin deficiency and changes in iron metabolism frequently result in anemia. Both of these underlying causes need to be targeted in treatment of anemia in these patients, first with repletion of iron stores and then with erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs).

ESAs are recommended in patients with anemia of CKD, with a goal hemoglobin level of 10 to 11.5 g/dL. However, these agents are not recommended in patients with active cancer. In several studies, including randomized controlled trials, patients with active cancer were found to have increased mortality and/or increased risk for tumor progression when treated with ESAs.

Ferritin, an acute-phase reactant, is an inaccurate indicator of iron stores in patients with CKD or chronic inflammation. The status of iron stores in these patients is more closely approximated by dividing the measured ferritin level by 3. In CKD, hemoglobin levels may improve with iron supplementation even when iron indices are in the normal range. For this reason, a trial of iron is recommended if the transferrin saturation is ≤30% or if the ferritin level is ≤500 ng/mL for optimal erythropoiesis. If oral iron does not increase the iron indices, a trial of intravenous iron can be given.

Although an increase in oral ferrous replacement is an option, it is unlikely to make a substantial difference since the patient's iron indices are relatively low despite the fact that she is already taking oral iron. In addition, this patient is taking two medications for constipation, and an increase in oral iron is likely to worsen her symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with advanced chronic kidney disease and active malignancy who has worsening normocytic anemia and a low-normal ferritin level is iron therapy.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman with stage 3 chronic kidney disease secondary to polycystic kidney disease has a blood pressure of 118/78 mm Hg. Her kidneys are enlarged on palpation, but her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable, and she has no symptoms. She takes lisinopril 10 mg once daily. She quit smoking several months ago. Several members of her family have a history of coronary artery disease.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Serum creatinine (mg/dL)
2.5
0.6–1.1

33
≥60

135
<130

55
≥46


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
220
125–200


The addition of which one of the following types of medication is most likely to reduce this patient’s risk for a major cardiovascular event?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The benefit of lipid-lowering agents in preventing major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with dyslipidemia is well established in the general population. The latest (2018) guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) suggest that clinicians calculate a risk score for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) to help guide decision-making in the management of blood cholesterol. Statin therapy is clearly indicated for patients with significant hyperlipidemia, for secondary prevention, and for those with a risk score >10%.

This patient’s 10-year risk of heart disease or stroke is 5.5% using the AHA/ACC calculator, but this calculator does not take into account the patient’s additional risk factors, including her family history and her chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD is considered a risk enhancer and should prompt discussions regarding use of statins, even if the risk score is below 10%, as is the case for this patient. Indeed, patients with CKD have a higher risk for cardiovascular disease than people in the general population because they have both traditional risk factors (such as hypertension) and nontraditional risk factors (such as alterations in mineral metabolism). For these patients, an ASCVD risk score of >5% should prompt a conversation about statins, and a risk score of >7.5% should prompt consideration of therapy. Patients who are taking a statin when they start dialysis may reasonably continue the medication, but for patients who are already on dialysis, there appears to be no benefit to starting a statin.

A Cochrane systematic review and meta-analysis (covering 50 studies with 45,000 patients) demonstrated that statins reduced the incidence of cardiovascular events and mortality by about 20% in patients with CKD who were not on dialysis. Most of these data were from subgroups of CKD patients within larger statin trials. In addition, the largest placebo-controlled trial devoted specifically to patients with CKD (the Study of Heart and Renal Protection [SHARP]) showed a significant benefit from simvastatin plus ezetimibe during 5 years of treatment. At enrollment, the 6200 SHARP participants who were not on dialysis had a mean estimated glomerular filtration rate of 27 mL/min/1.73 m2 and a mean LDL-cholesterol level of 112 mg/dL. Given the results of both the meta-analysis and the SHARP trial, it is reasonable to begin statin therapy in this patient.

Key learning point: The type of medication most likely to reduce the incidence of major cardiovascular events in non-dialysis-dependent, normotensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a statin.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

According to a recent meta-analysis, the benefits of antiplatelet therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease are unclear and potentially outweighed by the increased risk for bleeding.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents for reassessment of long-standing type 2 diabetes complicated by retinopathy and chronic kidney disease. Her current medications are lisinopril 20 mg daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily, and insulin detemir 26 units each evening. She reports mild fatigue but no other problems. She underwent colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy one year ago, and the results were normal.
Her blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg; otherwise, her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
12.0–16.0


Mean corpuscular volume (per μm3)
83
80–100


Iron (μg/dL)
40
30–160



Transferrin saturation (%)
16
15–45



Ferritin (ng/mL)
85
10–200


Folate (ng/mL)
10
3.1–17.5


Vitamin B12 (pg/mL)
507
>250


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.8
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following approaches to managing this patient’s anemia is most appropriate?

choices.text: Observe and repeat the laboratory tests in 6 months
Transfuse with 1 unit of red cells
Start monthly injection of an erythropoietin-stimulating agent
Initiate a 10-day course of intravenous iron therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient’s iron stores are not replenished, the hemoglobin level is likely to decrease further; thus, observation is not the preferred option.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood transfusion is not indicated in this mildly symptomatic patient. Furthermore, transfusion would increase the risk for antibody development and decrease the pool of potential matching donors if the patient ever requires kidney transplantation in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) should be considered only if the anemia persists after the iron stores are adequately replete. Current guidelines recommend avoiding ESAs in patients with hemoglobin levels ≥10 g/dL because of the potential for adverse cardiovascular outcomes. ESAs can be considered on a case-by-case basis in patients with hemoglobin levels <10 g/dL but can reasonably be avoided if such patients are asymptomatic. In this case, the patient has a hemoglobin level ≥10 g/dL and only mild symptoms, so use of an ESA would not be recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Although her iron stores are within the normal range, many patients with chronic kidney disease will have an improvement in their hemoglobin levels with iron supplementation. For this reason, a trial of oral iron is recommended if the transferrin saturation is ≤30% or the ferritin level is ≤500 ng/mL for optimal erythropoiesis. If patients do not improve with oral iron, intravenous iron can be considered.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has anemia of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Although her iron stores are within the normal range, many patients with CKD will have an improvement in their hemoglobin levels with iron supplementation. For this reason, a trial of oral iron is recommended if the transferrin saturation is ≤30% or the ferritin level is ≤500 ng/mL for optimal erythropoiesis. If patients do not improve with oral iron, intravenous iron can be considered. Care of patients with anemia in CKD should be individualized with a goal of limiting symptoms of anemia and avoiding transfusions.

Key learning point: In the presence of relatively low iron stores, anemia of chronic kidney disease is best initially treated with iron therapy, either orally or parenterally.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with atrial fibrillation and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is hospitalized with very painful, violaceous subcutaneous nodules on the thighs and painful fingers on both hands. He has a 7-year history of hemodialysis-treated end-stage kidney disease that is secondary to sarcoidosis. Several of the lesions are beginning to ulcerate.
His current medications (none of which were started in the recent past) are prednisone 5 mg daily, warfarin 5 mg daily, calcium acetate 2001 mg three times daily with meals, calcitriol 0.25 mg daily, intravenous darbepoetin 40 μg weekly, inhaled fluticasone, and inhaled ipratropium bromide.
On presentation, the patient has a blood pressure of 145/65 mm Hg, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a temperature of 37.5°C, and a BMI of 39. Lung examination reveals diffuse expiratory wheezing. Trace pretibial edema is present bilaterally. Skin examination reveals multiple small, violaceous subcutaneous nodules over the medial aspect of both thighs, which are very tender to palpation.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
137
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.0
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
105
98–106


Carbon dioxide (mEq/liter)
20

Creatinine (mg/dL)
4.5

11.0

Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
500
10–60


A radiograph of the hand is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum can occur with sarcoidosis, usually in pretibial areas, but does not explain the patient’s painful fingers and the radiograph findings, which are attributable to ischemia from severely calcified arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Warfarin-induced skin necrosis usually begins during the first few days of treatment with warfarin, and not in patients who have been taking the drug chronically.

C) CORRECT:

Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) typically occurs in patients with end-stage kidney disease and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. Medial calcification of arterioles (as seen in the hand radiograph) leads to tissue ischemia and necrosis. Lesions typically develop in areas of high adiposity, such as the thighs and abdomen. Risk factors include obesity, a history of autoimmune disease, severe hyperparathyroidism, and use of warfarin, prednisone, calcium-containing phosphate binders, or active vitamin D supplements. An elevated calcium-phosphorus product is typical of calciphylaxis.

Key learning point: The development of painful, violaceous subcutaneous bilateral thigh nodules in a patient with end-stage kidney disease, hypercalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia is calciphylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum, a cause of ulceration that typically involves the legs, is associated with ulcerative colitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and myeloma; it is not typically associated with the laboratory findings noted in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a serious condition characterized by progressive skin thickening. It has been linked to the administration of older formulations of gadolinium contrast in patients with severely reduced kidney function. However, newer gadolinium-based contrast agents are safe in patients with kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents for routine follow-up. His history is significant for heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction of 45% due to ischemic cardiomyopathy, myocardial infarction 3 years ago, hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage 3 with severely increased albuminuria, and type 2 diabetes. He has previously met with a dietician and currently adheres to a low-potassium diet. He also reports adherence to his current medications: chlorthalidone 25 mg daily, empagliflozin 10 mg daily, and lisinopril 20 mg daily.
He has a heart rate of 62 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 115/72 mm Hg, and a temperature of 37.2°C. On physical examination, he has moist mucous membranes. There is no evidence of ascites or pitting edema in the extremities.
Laboratory tests obtained 2 weeks ago yield the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
139
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.6
3.5–5.0


Carbon dioxide (mEq/liter)
23
21–30


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.2
0.8–1.3


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.2
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
4.0
3.0–4.5


Albumin (g/dL)
4.2
3.5–5.5


Repeat laboratory testing at today’s visit shows similar results.
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although fludrocortisone promotes potassium excretion, it also leads to sodium retention and increases blood pressure; thus, it should not be prescribed for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is used to manage metabolic acidosis, but this patient’s bicarbonate level is acceptable at this time, and the addition of sodium bicarbonate would have a limited effect on his potassium level.

C) INCORRECT:

Management of chronic hyperkalemia is challenging in patients who have both chronic kidney disease and a compelling indication for inhibition of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. In this case, the patient has two indications to continue his lisinopril: heart failure due to ischemic cardiomyopathy and severely increased albuminuria. Furthermore, on examination, his blood pressure and volume status appear to be optimized, so discontinuation of the lisinopril is likely to make management more challenging.

D) INCORRECT:

Addition of torsemide is a good choice in a patient who has hyperkalemia along with edema or suboptimally controlled blood pressure, but this patient does not require an additional diuretic.

E) CORRECT:

Management of chronic hyperkalemia is challenging in patients who have both chronic kidney disease and a compelling indication for inhibition of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. In this case, the patient has two indications to continue his lisinopril: heart failure due to ischemic cardiomyopathy and severely increased albuminuria. Furthermore, on examination, his blood pressure and volume status appear to be optimized, so discontinuation of the lisinopril is likely to make management more challenging. He has already restricted his dietary potassium intake.

The most appropriate next step for this patient is to start an oral potassium binder, such as sodium zirconium cyclosilicate or patiromer. Both of these agents are nonabsorbable and bind potassium within the intestine, leading to enhanced excretion of potassium in the stool. Patiromer exchanges calcium for potassium, whereas sodium zirconium cyclosilicate exchanges both hydrogen and sodium, which likely explains the dose-dependent edema seen with this medication. Both agents have been associated with gastrointestinal symptoms, and patiromer also carries a risk of hypomagnesemia.

Another oral potassium binder that might be considered is sodium polystyrene sulfonate (SPS), a cation-exchange resin that binds potassium in exchange for sodium in the gut. It has traditionally been used for acute hyperkalemia and is often used in ambulatory patients, either as an emergency measure to avoid a visit to the emergency department or in small regular doses daily or several times a week. Despite its widespread use, SPS has only modest efficacy and has been associated with intestinal necrosis in numerous case reports and a higher risk of hospitalization for adverse gastrointestinal events. SPS can also interfere with the absorption of other medications, which is a challenge for patients taking multiple medications because they would need to take this agent at a separate time from the others. Finally, because of its high sodium content, SPS has the potential to contribute to volume overload. For these reasons, SPS is usually reserved for situations in which other options are not available and the serum potassium level cannot be controlled.

Key learning point: Mild, chronic hyperkalemia in a patient with chronic kidney disease who is already adhering to a low-potassium diet and taking appropriate diuretics can be managed by starting an oral potassium binder (sodium zirconium cyclosilicate or patiromer).

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with known renal dysplasia presents for a health maintenance visit. Her glomerular filtration rate has declined in recent years, and she now has stage 4 chronic kidney disease. She reports that she usually takes calcitriol and sevelamer but missed her most recent appointment with her nephrologist, so she has not taken these medications for the past 3 weeks.
Her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, and other vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals no focal findings.
Basic laboratory studies are ordered.
In addition to elevated levels of blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine, which one of the following laboratory abnormalities is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The natural history of CKD can include multiple metabolic derangements. Congenital anomalies of the kidney often include tubular defects that increase the risk of hypokalemia, acid-base disorders, and impaired concentration. As the GFR declines (as it has in this patient), hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and acidosis occur because of diminished clearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Unless the underlying disease process has liver manifestations, hyperbilirubinemia would not be expected in a patient with CKD.

C) INCORRECT:

As the GFR declines (as it has in this patient), hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and acidosis occur because of diminished clearance.

D) INCORRECT:

As the GFR declines (as it has in this patient), hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and acidosis occur because of diminished clearance.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) in children can result from a wide range of congenital or acquired processes, including glomerulopathies, reflux or obstruction, infection, hereditary nephropathies, hypoplasia or dysplasia, and vascular disease. Renal function is often characterized by stages of CKD because patients tend to have common problems at certain stages regardless of the etiology of the disorder. The stages of CKD range from stage 1, when the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is normal but renal pathology is present, to stage 5, when the GFR is <15 mL/min/1.73 m2 .

The natural history of CKD can include multiple metabolic derangements. Congenital anomalies of the kidney often include tubular defects that increase the risk of hypokalemia, acid-base disorders, and impaired concentration. As the GFR declines (as it has in this patient), hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and acidosis occur because of diminished clearance. Hyperphosphatemia can be treated with sevelamer, which binds to phosphate in the gut and is excreted.

Hypocalcemia may occur in CKD as a result of impaired intestinal absorption of calcium related to low levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). Vitamin D is converted to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in the kidney by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase. As CKD develops, this enzyme becomes less active, and circulating levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D decline; as these levels decline, less calcium is absorbed and hypocalcemia develops. In addition, patients with CKD are often advised to follow a low-phosphorus diet, which is also usually low in calcium. To treat hypocalcemia, patients with CKD are advised to take calcium supplements for a total daily elemental calcium intake of 1000 to 2000 mg/day; calcitriol can be added to increase the calcium.

In response to low serum calcium, low 1,25-hydroxyvitamin D, and elevated phosphate levels, the body increases production of parathyroid hormone, resulting in secondary hyperparathyroidism, which can also be treated with calcitriol.

Key learning point: A basic metabolic panel for a patient with advanced chronic kidney disease will show elevated levels of blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine, as well as low serum bicarbonate, elevated potassium, and low calcium.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue and weakness. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration was 13.5% 12 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Examination shows lower extremity edema. Serum studies show:


K+

5.1 mEq/L


Phosphorus
5.0 mg/dL


Ca2+

7.8 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate parameter for early detection of this patient’s renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of urinary red blood cell casts indicates glomerulonephritis (GN). This finding is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN can result in red or cola-colored urine, mild edema (due to the relatively limited loss of albumin), and hypertension (i.e., nephritic syndrome). However, diabetic nephropathy classically leads to nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy leads to nephrotic syndrome, which typically manifests with hypoproteinemia. However, total protein is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only decreases once there is significant glomerular damage.

C) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy. Progression of glomerular damage (nodular glomerulosclerosis) leads to increased urinary loss of albumin, which can manifest as nephrotic syndrome. The extent of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy also correlates with the risk of future cardiovascular events. ACE inhibitors can prevent the progression of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, BUN is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, it is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with features of diabetic nephropathy (elevated creatinine and BUN levels, arterial hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, edema).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of fatigue and swelling of the lower legs for 3 weeks. One year ago, he had an 85% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery, for which he received 2 stents. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C 5 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and arterial hypertension. Current medications include aspirin, metformin, and ramipril. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Serum



 Na+
137 mEq/L


 K+
5.2 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.9 mg/dL


 Albumin
3.6 g/dL


Urinalysis discloses 1+ glucose and 3+ protein. A renal biopsy shows sclerosis in the capillary tufts and arterial hyalinosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition can be associated with chronic infections (such as hepatitis C) and would result in proteinuria and peripheral edema, amyloidosis classically presents in patients with multiple myeloma and signs of extrarenal organ involvement, such as restrictive cardiomyopathy, as opposed to coronary artery disease. Moreover, renal biopsy in amyloidosis would show green birefringence under Congo red stain.

B) CORRECT:

Hypertensive nephrosclerosis results from renal vascular injury secondary to long-standing arterial hypertension. Sclerosis in the capillary tufts and hyaline arteriolosclerosis, as seen on kidney biopsy, are caused by chronic damage from increased capillary hydrostatic pressure in the glomeruli as well as ischemic damage from progressive narrowing of the renal arterioles. Patients with nephrosclerosis present with elevated blood pressure and laboratory findings that suggest impaired renal function, including elevated BUN and creatinine and presence of proteinuria. Some patients may also have microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Ultrasound typically shows small, atrophic kidneys.

Patients with hypertensive nephrosclerosis initially have microalbuminuria but eventually develop macroalbuminuria as the disease progresses.

C) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition is associated with hepatitis C and may cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, membranous nephropathy would also cause hypoalbuminemia, and thickening of the glomerular capillary loops and basal membrane would be evident on light microscopy. The absence of these findings in this patient makes membranous nephropathy an unlikely cause of his end-stage renal disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Although this condition is associated with hepatitis C and would cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, MPGN would also cause hypoalbuminemia and basement membrane thickening and splitting with IgG or C3 deposits (“train-track” appearance) would be evident on electron microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a possible cause of chronic kidney disease and secondary hypertension (HTN). Although this patient has multiple risk factors for renal artery stenosis, including HTN, atherosclerotic disease, and diabetes, physical exam findings in renal artery stenosis would include auscultation of a bruit over the flank or abdomen. The absence of an abdominal bruit and the findings from this patient's kidney biopsy suggest his end-stage renal disease is caused by a different mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with peripheral edema, anemia, increased creatinine and BUN, proteinuria, and hyperkalemia. These features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She reports feeling tired sometimes and having itchy skin. Over the past 2 years, the amount of urine she passes has been slowly decreasing. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic nephropathy. Physical examination shows 1+ pitting edema around the ankles bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL


Serum



 Albumin
4 g/dL


 Na+

145 mEq/L


 K+

5.1 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
46 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.1 mg/dL


Which of the following complications is the most common cause of death in patients receiving long-term treatment for this patient's renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients undergoing renal replacement therapy are at increased risk of developing malignancy (up to sevenfold higher than the general population) due to many factors (e.g., renal replacement therapy increases the risk of acquired renal cystic disease, which is associated with renal cell carcinoma). However, malignancy is not the most common cause of death among these patients.

B) INCORRECT:

The discontinuation of hemodialysis is common among patients with end-stage renal disease and is the third most common cause of death among patients receiving hemodialysis in the US. The reasons are numerous, including advanced age, discomfort during dialysis sessions, and the limited autonomy associated with frequent hemodialysis. Survival time after discontinuation of RRT varies with the underlying condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection (e.g., shunt infection) is the second most common cause of death among patients receiving hemodialysis. Infectious complications of dialysis are particularly lethal in older patients (because of reduced immune function due to aging and poor nutritional status) and renal transplant recipients (due to immunosuppressive therapy). However, infection is not the most common cause of death among patients receiving renal replacement therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Anemia is common in patients undergoing renal replacement therapy, and has a multifactorial etiology (e.g., decreased RBC production due to lack of erythropoietin in chronic kidney disease, increased RBC destruction due to hemolysis). However, anemia is not the most common cause of death among these patients.

E) CORRECT:

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in patients undergoing renal replacement therapy, accounting for almost half of all deaths in this population, with a mortality rate up to 20-fold greater than in the general population. Sudden cardiac death is the single most common form of death in this population, followed by acute myocardial infarction. The increased mortality rate may be in part due to the traditional risk factors for CVD (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia) also being risk factors for end-stage renal disease. Therefore, the prevalence of these risk factors for CVD is high in patients on dialysis. Furthermore, patients on dialysis have additional risk factors for CVD due to renal dysfunction (e.g., malnutrition, increased catabolic state, inflammation).

CVD is also the most common cause of death in patients receiving a kidney transplant.
questions.hint: This patient's history of diabetic nephropathy in combination with oliguria, pruritus, anemia, and azotemia suggests chronic kidney disease that will most likely require renal replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents for reassessment of long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by retinopathy and chronic kidney disease. Her current medications are lisinopril, amlodipine, and insulin. She reports mild fatigue but no other problems. She underwent colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy one year ago, and the results were normal. Her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. The patient's hemoglobin is 10.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 83 μm3, and transferrin saturation is 16% (N = 15–45) Serum iron, ferritin, folate, and vitamin B12 levels are within normal limits. Which one of the following approaches to managing this patient’s anemia is most appropriate?

Initiate a 10-day course of intravenous iron therapy

A) INCORRECT:

If the patient’s iron stores are not replenished, the hemoglobin level is likely to decrease further; thus, observation is not the preferred option.

B) INCORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

Use of erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) should be considered only if the anemia persists after the iron stores are adequately replete. Current guidelines recommend avoiding ESAs in patients with hemoglobin levels ≥10 g/dL because of the potential for adverse cardiovascular outcomes. ESAs can be considered on a case-by-case basis in patients with hemoglobin levels <10 g/dL but can reasonably be avoided if such patients are asymptomatic. In this case, the patient has a hemoglobin level ≥10 g/dL and only mild symptoms, so use of an ESA would not be recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Although her iron stores are within the normal range, many patients with CKD will have an improvement in their hemoglobin levels with iron supplementation. For this reason, a trial of oral iron is recommended if the transferrin saturation is ≤30% or the ferritin level is ≤500 ng/mL for optimal erythropoiesis. If patients do not improve with oral iron, intravenous iron can be considered.

E) CORRECT:

Although this patient's iron stores are within the normal range, many patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) will have an improvement in their hemoglobin levels with iron supplementation. For this reason, a trial of oral iron supplementation is recommended if the transferrin saturation is ≤ 30% or the ferritin level is ≤ 500 ng/mL for optimal erythropoiesis. If patients do not improve with oral iron, intravenous iron can be considered. Care of patients with anemia in CKD should be individualized with a goal of limiting symptoms of anemia and avoiding transfusions.

Key learning point: In the presence of relatively low iron stores, anemia of chronic kidney disease is best initially treated with iron therapy, either orally or parenterally.
questions.hint: This patient has anemia of chronic kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, itching of the skin, and progressive leg swelling. She has been passing only small amounts of urine. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetic polyneuropathy. Her current medications include insulin, torsemide, lisinopril, and synthetic erythropoietin. There is 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Serum studies show:


Na+

137 mEq/L


K+

5.3 mEq/L


HCO3−

20 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
85 mg/dL


Creatinine
8 mg/dL


pH
7.25


Which of the following long-term treatments would best improve quality of life and maximize survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Although on average cadaveric kidney transplants function for approx. 14 years, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for this 45-year-old patient, because it is not associated with the greatest survival benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of fluid overload (e.g., peripheral edema). Although fluid intake should be restricted to approximately 2 L/day in order to prevent edema in this patient, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for a patient with ESRD.

C) CORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. In these cases, it is associated with a greater long-term survival rate and a better quality of life than dialysis. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation of the transplant in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Transplants received from a living donor (e.g., a family member) have a better prognosis than cadaveric kidney transplants (even in the setting of MHC mismatch). For cadaveric kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 88%, while it is 71% at 5 years. For living donor kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 94%, while it is 84% at 5 years. In comparison to hemodialysis, more patients with ESRD who undergo kidney transplantation regain bodily functions, including endocrine function.

Key learning point: Living donor kidney transplantation offers the best long-term improvement in quality of life and survival for patients with end-stage renal disease compared to dialysis or cadaveric transplantation.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with acidosis, electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia), ingestion of toxins (increased BUN), fluid overload (edema), and uremic symptoms (itching of the skin), all of which are indications for dialysis. Although renal replacement therapy is indicated in this patient, peritoneal dialysis would not be the best long-term treatment because of a variety of potential complications that can occur (e.g., infections, metabolic disturbances) if this method is maintained incorrectly and the need for daily, time-consuming treatments.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with CKD require renal replacement therapy (RRT), and hemodialysis is the most commonly used form of RRT in the United States. Although RRT is indicated in this patient and is necessary to bridge the time to definitive treatment, hemodialysis should not be continued as a long-term treatment if another option is available, as hemodialysis is associated with a variety of potential complications (e.g., thrombosis, infection, heart failure) that may impact survival. Moreover, it must be administered at least 3 times per week, which significantly reduces quality of life. A treatment associated with a better survival rate and quality of life should be pursued if available. The 5-year survival rate of the patients on hemodialysis is approx. 30–40% overall, but is only 20% for patients with diabetic nephropathy, which is the likely etiology in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetic nephropathy and presents with fatigue, loss of appetite, pruritus, lower extremity edema, and oliguria. In combination with the patient's hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, uremia, and increased serum creatinine, these features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text:

Medications include insulin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows pitting edema of both ankles. Serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dL. increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased PTH and elevated vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate levels are consistent with vitamin D toxicity. Excess vitamin D (e.g., exogenous supplementation) increases intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate, which in turn inhibits PTH secretion. A patient with CKD is unlikely to have vitamin D toxicity.

B) CORRECT:

CKD is associated with vitamin D deficiency due to decreased 1-alpha hydroxylase activity. By reducing intestinal absorption of calcium, vitamin D deficiency also causes low calcium levels, which in turn stimulates the secretion of PTH, leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although high levels of PTH normally stimulate renal reabsorption of calcium and excretion of phosphate, phosphate excretion is impaired in CKD, resulting instead in hyperphosphatemia. Other laboratory abnormalities in patients with CKD include hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Key learning point: Chronic kidney disease typically causes increased PTH, decreased vitamin D and calcium, and increased phosphorus due to impaired phosphate excretion and reduced activation of vitamin D.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated PTH and calcium levels and decreased vitamin D and phosphate levels are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. High levels of PTH increase bone turnover as well as renal calcium reabsorption and phosphate excretion. Vitamin D decreases in response to elevated calcium levels. Although CKD is associated with vitamin D deficiency, concurrent renal tubular dysfunction would result in a different constellation of laboratory findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated PTH and low vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate levels are consistent with vitamin D deficiency. Decreased levels of vitamin D lead to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH secretion. High levels of PTH, in turn, stimulate renal phosphate excretion, leading to hypophosphatemia. Although CKD is associated with vitamin D deficiency, renal tubular dysfunction would result in a different constellation of laboratory findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased phosphate levels and decreased PTH, vitamin D, and calcium levels are consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism. Low PTH levels lead to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. Vitamin D is usually low (or normal) because low PTH levels do not stimulate renal vitamin D production. CKD typically causes a different parathyroid gland disorder.
questions.hint: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) have decreased activity of the 1-alpha-hydroxylase enzyme.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, muscle cramps, and loss of appetite. Over the last two weeks, he has experienced worsening confusion and pruritic skin lesions. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. He has not undergone dialysis before. Physical examination shows asterixis, bilateral pedal edema, and decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution. Vital signs are stable (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
650 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Estimated GFR

9 mL/min/1.73 m2

90 - 120 mL/min/1.73 m2



Potassium
6.0 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L



What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous sodium bicarbonate can temporarily manage hyperkalemia by shifting potassium into cells, especially in acidemia. However, this patient has advanced renal failure with uremic symptoms, requiring comprehensive management of uremic toxins and metabolic disturbances. Sodium bicarbonate does not address these issues and may worsen fluid overload due to added sodium.

B) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics can alleviate fluid overload and promote renal potassium excretion in moderate renal impairment. However, with an eGFR of 9 mL/min/1.73 m2, the patient's renal function is too compromised for effective diuretic response. Uremic symptoms and hyperkalemia require more than diuretic therapy.

C) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits advanced chronic kidney disease with a severely reduced estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 9 mL/min/1.73 m2 and elevated creatinine levels. Clinical signs of uremia, such as confusion, asterixis, and pruritic skin lesions, indicate the need for urgent intervention. Additionally, the elevated potassium level of 6.0 mmol/L poses a risk for cardiac arrhythmias. Urgent hemodialysis is necessary to rapidly clear uremic toxins, correct hyperkalemia, and manage fluid overload, addressing the critical metabolic derangements present.

Key learning point: In patients with advanced CKD presenting with uremic symptoms and significant electrolyte imbalances, initiation of dialysis is the most appropriate management step to address uremic neuropathy and other complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution suggests diabetic peripheral neuropathy, often evaluated with nerve conduction studies. However, the patient's acute presentation with uremic symptoms and severe renal impairment necessitates urgent management of metabolic derangements, not nerve evaluation.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease presents for routine evaluation. He has recently started eating more fresh tomatoes and bananas to consume a 'healthier diet.' Physical examination is normal. He inquires about safe dietary choices (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Potassium
5.8 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L


Creatinine
300 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


eGFR
24 mL/min/1.73m²
90 - 120 mL/min/1.73m²



Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Increase dietary protein to reduce the risk of hyperkalemia
Substitute table salt with potassium-based salt alternatives
Adopt an unrestricted fruit and vegetable intake for better overall health
Limit consumption of high-potassium foods, including tomatoes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing dietary protein does not lower serum potassium levels. In advanced chronic kidney disease, protein restrictions are often recommended to reduce renal workload. Protein-rich diets can contribute to metabolic acidosis, exacerbating hyperkalemia. Many protein sources are also high in potassium, making this recommendation inappropriate for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium-based salt substitutes can increase potassium intake, which is risky in patients with impaired renal function, such as those with stage 4 chronic kidney disease. This patient already has elevated serum potassium, and additional potassium intake could exacerbate hyperkalemia and increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

C) INCORRECT:

While fruits and vegetables are generally healthy, many are high in potassium, which can exacerbate hyperkalemia in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease. This patient has elevated potassium levels and reduced renal clearance, necessitating a diet that limits high-potassium foods to prevent complications.

D) CORRECT:

In stage 4 chronic kidney disease, reduced glomerular filtration rate impairs potassium excretion, increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. Foods like tomatoes are high in potassium and can elevate serum levels, as seen in this patient's potassium level of 5.8 mmol/L. Restricting high-potassium foods is crucial to prevent complications such as cardiac arrhythmias. Dietary recommendations should be tailored to the severity of renal impairment and laboratory findings.

Key learning point: Patients with CKD stage 4 should consume high-potassium foods like tomatoes in moderation to prevent hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance for the past two months. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 4 chronic kidney disease. He denies noticing any blood in his stool. On examination, he appears pale and has conjunctival pallor. Vital signs are within normal limits. His red blood cell indices have remained stable over the last six months (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
85 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
88 fL
80 - 95 fL


Ferritin
250 μg/L
20 - 300 μg/L


Creatinine
300 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which factor best explains the primary cause of his anemia?

choices.text: Bone marrow infiltration by malignant cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) impairs the function of peritubular interstitial fibroblasts, which are responsible for erythropoietin (EPO) production in the kidney. In advanced CKD, these cells are damaged by chronic ischemia and fibrosis, leading to reduced EPO synthesis. EPO stimulates red blood cell production in the bone marrow, so its deficiency results in normocytic, normochromic anemia despite adequate iron stores. This explains the patient's fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. Understanding this mechanism is crucial for managing anemia in CKD, often treated with recombinant EPO.

Key learning point: In patients with chronic kidney disease, anemia is commonly caused by erythropoietin deficiency due to the kidneys' reduced ability to produce this hormone.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow infiltration by malignant cells often causes anemia with additional cytopenias and systemic symptoms like bone pain or weight loss. This patient has stable red blood cell indices, normocytic anemia, and no systemic symptoms, making marrow infiltration unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency from insufficient dietary intake usually presents with microcytic anemia and low ferritin levels. This patient has normocytic MCV and normal ferritin, indicating adequate iron stores. The anemia is more consistent with reduced erythropoietin production due to chronic kidney disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic gastrointestinal blood loss typically causes iron deficiency anemia, characterized by microcytic red blood cells and low serum ferritin. This patient has normocytic MCV and normal ferritin levels, indicating preserved iron stores. Additionally, he denies noticing blood in his stool, making chronic gastrointestinal blood loss unlikely.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, reduced exercise tolerance, and new-onset dyspnea on exertion for two months. He has a 12-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 4 chronic kidney disease with a recent eGFR of 21 mL/min/1.73 m2. Physical examination shows mild pallor with stable vital signs (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
85 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
93 fL
80 - 95 fL


Ferritin
400 μg/L
20 - 300 μg/L


Transferrin
2.8 g/L
2.3 - 3.9 g/L


Vitamin B12

500 ng/L
160 - 900 ng/L


Stool




 Occult blood
Negative
Negative



What is the most appropriate next step in management of his anemia?

choices.text: Regular packed red blood cell transfusions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regular transfusions temporarily raise hemoglobin levels but do not address the underlying erythropoietin deficiency in CKD. The elevated ferritin level indicates sufficient iron stores, reducing the likelihood of iron deficiency anemia. Transfusions carry risks such as iron overload and alloimmunization, complicating potential future kidney transplantation.

B) CORRECT:

In chronic kidney disease (CKD), reduced renal production of erythropoietin leads to normocytic anemia, as indicated by normal mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and low hemoglobin levels. The elevated ferritin level confirms adequate iron stores, suggesting the anemia is due to insufficient erythropoietin. Subcutaneous erythropoietin therapy addresses this deficit, enhancing red blood cell production and alleviating symptoms like fatigue and dyspnea. This approach aligns with management guidelines for anemia in advanced CKD.

Key learning point: In patients with chronic kidney disease and anemia, erythropoietin therapy is indicated to address anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production by the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

The elevated ferritin level (400 μg/L) suggests adequate iron stores, arguing against iron deficiency anemia. In CKD, increased ferritin often reflects inflammation and impaired iron utilization. High-dose oral iron would not address the anemia's underlying cause, which is decreased erythropoietin production.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's normal vitamin B12 level (500 ng/L) and normal MCV argue against vitamin B12 deficiency, which typically presents with macrocytic anemia. The anemia is more likely related to decreased erythropoietin production in CKD, not vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease presents to the clinic with persistent fatigue, bone pain, and muscle weakness for the past 3 months. He has a 2-year history of progressive renal insufficiency managed with dietary restriction and antihypertensive medications. Physical examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness over his long bones, but no joint swelling (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Calcium
2.0 mmol/L
2.15 - 2.62 mmol/L


Phosphate, inorganic
2.2 mmol/L
0.82 - 1.51 mmol/L


Parathyroid hormone (intact PTH levels)
88 pmol/L
1.1 - 5.3 pmol/L


Estimated glomerular filtration rate
22 mL/min/1.73 m²
90 - 120 mL/min/1.73 m²



Which of the following interventions is the most appropriate to address his bone-related findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), the kidneys lose the ability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This deficiency leads to decreased intestinal calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism. The elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels cause bone pain and muscle weakness, characteristic of renal osteodystrophy. Oral calcitriol therapy increases calcium absorption and modulates PTH secretion, addressing the metabolic disturbances and mitigating bone demineralization associated with CKD.

Key learning point: In patients with chronic kidney disease, oral calcitriol is used to manage secondary hyperparathyroidism and bone disorders due to impaired conversion of vitamin D to its active form.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous bisphosphonates treat conditions with primary bone resorption, such as osteoporosis, but do not address the mineral imbalances in CKD. In CKD, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated PTH levels result from decreased calcitriol production and phosphate retention. Bisphosphonates may suppress bone remodeling and worsen adynamic bone disease in CKD.

C) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous parathyroid hormone (PTH) injections are used in osteoporosis with low bone turnover but are inappropriate in CKD with secondary hyperparathyroidism. In CKD, excessive endogenous PTH secretion already drives bone pathology. Exogenous PTH would exacerbate bone turnover and resorption.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholecalciferol requires renal conversion to active calcitriol, which is impaired in CKD. High-dose cholecalciferol does not correct the active vitamin D deficiency and may increase phosphate absorption, worsening hyperphosphatemia. CKD-related mineral bone disorder requires interventions that bypass renal activation.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue over three months to the clinic. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He denies recent blood loss, medication changes, gastrointestinal bleeding, or easy bruising. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctivae. Repeat values are unchanged (see lab results).

Blood pressure
135/80 mm Hg



Test

130 - 170 g/L


MCV
88 fL
80 - 95 fL


Reticulocyte
0.4%

415 μmol/L

Ferritin
220 μg/L

Vitamin B12

310 ng/L
160 - 900 ng/L


Folic acid
14 μg/L
